evaluation_data.query: What are the tax implications of stock options?
How do I report ISO exercise on my tax return?

example_documents.text: Incentive Stock Options (ISOs) under IRC Section 422 provide favorable tax treatment when specific holding period requirements are met. Exercise of ISOs does not trigger ordinary income tax but may trigger Alternative Minimum Tax (AMT). Upon sale, if holding periods are satisfied (1 year from exercise, 2 years from grant), gains are taxed as long-term capital gains.

Non-Qualified Stock Options (NSOs) are governed by IRC Section 83. Upon exercise, the spread between exercise price and fair market value is taxed as ordinary income subject to withholding. Subsequent gains or losses upon sale are treated as capital gains or losses.

Equity compensation encompasses various instruments including stock options (ISO and NSO), restricted stock units (RSUs), and employee stock purchase plans (ESPPs). Each has distinct tax implications and regulatory requirements under federal and state law.

domain_contexts.finance: Financial documents use formal terminology including IRC sections, tax treatment classifications, and regulatory framework references.
domain_contexts.legal: Legal documents employ precise statutory language, case citations, and formal legal constructs.
domain_contexts.technical: Technical documentation uses industry-specific terminology, API references, and implementation details.
domain_contexts.hr: HR policies use formal employment terminology, policy frameworks, and compliance language.
